Award.AwardTitle: GP-IMPACT: Integrating Geoscience to Engage Majors with Mathematics: iGEM2
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part I
At The University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), mathematics courses leading to Calculus constitute a major obstruction to success for alarming numbers of STEM-intended majors. This fact reflects a challenge faced by universities across the country. Our goals are to (1) improve success of intended STEM majors at UTA in mathematics courses that lead to Calculus, courses taken primarily by STEM-intended majors, but yielding D-F-Withdraw rates >60%, and (2) introduce first and second year students to the geosciences and related career pathways before they decide on a major, thereby increasing the number and diversity of students who choose to major in the geosciences. We will do this by modifying the laboratory/recitation component of Math 1302 (College Algebra) by integrating geoscience research of The Ohio State University (OSU) and UTA faculty into the mathematics curriculum, reaching approximately 1,000 students per semester. Weekly lab meetings in the mathematics courses will incorporate a video presentation by geoscience faculty describing how the mathematical skill is essential for his/her scientific research, and exercises the students perform will be cast in the context of that research project, followed by problem-solving activities that synthesize mathematical concepts and apply the concepts with problems related to geoscience research. In this way, the mathematical abstraction will be connected with geoscience content crossing the fields of geophysics, environmental geochemistry, and oceanography. This is a strategic partnership, as the geosciences incorporate research methods from across all of STEM and are therefore likely to be relatable to a broad range of STEM-intended students. This collaboration will empower beginning STEM students by placing abstract mathematical concepts in a scientific context at a critical transition, which constitutes statistically a major stumbling block for many STEM-intended majors. At the same time, it will expose students early in their college experience to geoscience as a potential major. This project will be made possible by building a new partnership between the School of Earth Science at OSU and Mathematics at UTA. Success of the project will be determined by monitoring D-F-W rates of this course, evaluate students? perceptions of the geosciences and confidence in mathematics, and tracking students through declaration of their major and beyond. In the final year of the project, the model implemented at UTA will be propagated to OSU, demonstrating long term transportability and sustainability.

Part II
Freshman level math courses often form a roadblock for STEM-intended students, particularly when students do not test directly into Calculus when they enter college. This is certainly true at The University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), an access-oriented university. Calculus is the first mathematics course in all natural science degree plans at UTA; however, Algebra or Precalculus are common mathematics entry points for STEM-intended majors especially those who begin their major through nontraditional pathways. In 2012, UTA had the highest acceptance rate and highest number of new transfer students (8,649) in the country (National Student Clearinghouse Research Center) and this trend continues. Given these statistics, and the fact that the proposed work will directly affect ~1000 students per semester, this project will have an enormous impact on a diverse population of at-risk students who aspire to graduating in a STEM degree. Our goals are to (1) improve success of intended STEM majors at UTA in mathematics courses that lead to Calculus, courses taken primarily by STEM-intended majors, but yielding D-F-Withdraw rates >60%, and (2) introduce first and second year students to the geosciences and related career pathways before they decide on a major, thereby increasing the number and diversity of students who choose to major in the geosciences. We will recast College Algebra concepts in the context of research areas of Earth Science Faculty at The Ohio State University (OSU) and UTA without changing the content of the current course. In this way, we will empower beginning STEM students by placing abstract mathematical concepts in a scientific context - crossing the fields of geophysics, environmental geochemistry, and oceanography - at a critical transition which constitutes statistically a major stumbling block for many of STEM-intended majors. This is a new strategic partnership, as the geosciences incorporate research methods from across all of STEM and are therefore likely to be relatable to a broad range of STEM-intended students. At the same time, it will expose students early in their college experience to geoscience as a potential major. Success of the project will be determined by monitoring D-F-W rates of this course, evaluate students? perceptions of the geosciences and confidence in mathematics, and tracking students through declaration of their major and beyond. In the final year of the project, the model implemented at UTA will be propagated to OSU, demonstrating long term transportability and sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
iGEM2 provided support for a new partnership between earth scientists and mathematicians to contextualize mathematics content with geoscience concepts in the College Algebra curriculum at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), a Hispanic-serving institution, thereby exposing STEM-intended majors to cutting-edge concepts and careers in the geosciences. The project goals were to (1) improve success of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors in UTA mathematics courses that lead to Calculus, beginning with Math 1302 - College Algebra, while (2) creating a new pathway for a diverse group of STEM-intended majors to be exposed to geoscience careers and choose to major in Earth and Environmental Sciences. Promising results from this new collaboration led to a successful continuing collaborative award from the National Science Foundation to develop, implement, and assess curricular materials that contextualize geoscience concepts for Math 1402 Preparations for Calculus, which started in Fall 2019.


Beginning in Summer 2018, students in College Algebra at UTA were surveyed pre- and post-course to measure their attitudes toward mathematics, self-efficacy in mathematics, attitudes toward science, perceptions of geosciences, and knowledge about science and geoscience jobs. More than 1600 pre-course student surveys have been collected, with fewer post-course surveys completed. This class typically has a high percentage of STEM-intended majors (58.8% of students surveyed) and is one of the first courses many students in college take (on average students surveyed have completed less than two semesters of college). 


Beginning in Spring 2020 we implemented four modules of new contextualized problems into the College Algebra Learning Objectives modifying four of the five units comprising the College Algebra curriculum. We did not modify the preparation unit. The new curricular material included modified geoscience-themed homework problems, challenge (extra credit) problems, problem-solving labs, and an accompanying video introducing the geoscience content illustrating the mathematics concepts and featuring a professional scientist who actively uses the mathematics concepts in their work. The videos are accessed through our YouTube Channel iGEM2. The mathematics concepts aligned with the geoscience modules are: (1) Linear Equations, Functions, and Domains - Earthquakes and Earthquake Early Warning System; (2) Parabolas, Polynomial and Rational Functions - Human Interaction with Groundwater; (3) Exponential and Logarithmic Functions - Atmospheric CO2 and Ocean Acidification; and (4) Systems of Linear Equations, Systems of Inequalities, and Matrix Operations - Earth's Energy Resources. 


In order to best understand the impact of the new geoscience-themed mathematics curricular material, baseline data was collected pre-implementation in the unmodified course at the same time that the new material was being developed. Due to COVID-19 restrictions, the two semesters which fully implemented the new curricular material included additional modifications for instruction: on-line teaching after March 2020 for Spring 2020 and a modified schedule for in person instruction for Fall 2020. By comparing matched pre- and post-course surveys for Fall 2020 (fully implemented modified course content, n = 124) with Spring 2019 (no modified course content or baseline, n = 96), we have made a few initial observations: (1) attitudes towards the geosciences did not dramatically decrease when adding geoscience-themed mathematics, (2) awareness of geosciences careers increased more when implementing the new curricular material, and (3) female students were more inclined to take a geoscience course at the end of the semester when geoscience-themed curricular material was added. We will continue to gather data in College Algebra to verify initial findings during these unusual times, supported by the continuing collaborative award.

 

Analysis of the pre-course survey data, which included surveys from 1611 students (33.8% identified as Hispanic, 29.0% as White, 19.4% as Black, 14.3% as Asian, 3.3% as other, and 0.2% as Native American), provided new information on what students value most in an ideal career early in their college experience. On average, students cared very little about working outdoors or in an office. Students rated two factors, "helping people and society" and "helping the environment", most important. Women rated these higher than men, while underrepresented minority (Hispanic, Black, and Native American) men rated "helping the environment" higher than nonminority men. Although most students surveyed agreed that careers in the geosciences "help people and society" and "help the environment"; they agreed more strongly that careers in biology help people, society, and the environment. Very few of these same students, however, know what careers exist in the geosciences (13.8%), in contrast to careers in biology (58.3%). 


As a measure of growth in student success, we tracked the percent of students in each semester of College Algebra who earned a grade of D, F, or W.  We have seen a steady downward trend in D, F, or W percentage each semester since the implementation of the modified curriculum in Spring 2020, indicating greater student success.


Last Modified: 01/28/2021
Modified by: Theresa A Jorgensen
